a.g: He said, "My Lord, indeed my bones have weakened, and my head has filled with white, and never have I been in my supplication to You, my Lord, unhappy.
And indeed, I fear the successors after me, and my wife has been barren, so give me from Yourself an heir
Who will inherit me and inherit from the family of Jacob. And make him, my Lord, pleasing [to You]."
[He was told], "O Zechariah, indeed We give you good tidings of a boy whose name will be John. We have not assigned to any before [this] name."
He said, "My Lord, how will I have a boy when my wife has been barren and I have reached extreme old age?"
[An angel] said, "Thus [it will be]; your Lord says, 'It is easy for Me, for I created you before, while you were nothing.' "
[Zechariah] said, "My Lord, make for me a sign." He said, "Your sign is that you will not speak to the people for three nights, [being] sound."
So he came out to his people from the prayer chamber and signaled to them to exalt [Allah] in the morning and afternoon.
[Allah] said, "O John, take the Scripture with determination." And We gave him judgement [while yet] a boy

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
Third: Presence of the Heart (Qalb) and abandoning the talk of the Soul (Nafs). It is said in the interpretation of: 'O Yahya, take the Book with strength' meaning with seriousness and diligence, and taking it with seriousness is to be devoted to it during its recitation, diverting one's concern (Himma) to it away from other things. It was said to someone: 'When you recite the Quran, do you talk to your Soul (Nafs) about something?' He replied: 'Is there anything more beloved to me than the Quran that I would talk to my Soul (Nafs) about it?' Some of the predecessors (Salaf) would repeat a verse if their Heart (Qalb) was not in it. This quality is generated from what precedes it of veneration, for the one who venerates the speech he recites rejoices in it, finds intimacy (Uns) with it, and does not neglect it. In the Quran is what the Heart (Qalb) finds intimacy (Uns) with, if the reciter is worthy of it. So how can one seek intimacy (Uns) through thought in other than it while he is in a pleasure-garden and a place of viewing? The one who views in pleasure-gardens does not think about other than them. It has been said that in the Quran are arenas, gardens, pavilions, brides, brocades, meadows, and inns. The Mims are the arenas of the Quran, the RÄs are its gardens, the HÄs are its pavilions, the Musabbihat are its brides, the Hamims are its brocades, the Mufassal is its meadows, and the inns are what is besides that. So when the reciter enters the arenas, plucks from the gardens, enters the pavilions, witnesses the brides, wears the brocades, strolls in the meadows, and lodges in the rooms of the inns, that engrosses him and occupies him from other than it, so his Heart (Qalb) does not stray and his thought does not scatter.

a.g: She said, "Indeed, I seek refuge in the Most Merciful from you, [so leave me], if you should be fearing of Allah."
He said, "I am only the messenger of your Lord to give you [news of] a pure boy."
She said, "How can I have a boy while no man has touched me and I have not been unchaste?"
He said, "Thus [it will be]; your Lord says, 'It is easy for Me, and We will make him a sign to the people and a mercy from Us. And it is a matter [already] decreed.' "
So she conceived him, and she withdrew with him to a remote place.
And the pains of childbirth drove her to the trunk of a palm tree. She said, "Oh, I wish I had died before this and was in oblivion, forgotten."
But he called her from below her, "Do not grieve; your Lord has provided beneath you a stream.
And shake toward you the trunk of the palm tree; it will drop upon you ripe, fresh dates.
So eat and drink and be contented. And if you see from among humanity anyone, say, 'Indeed, I have vowed to the Most Merciful abstention, so I will not speak today to [any] man.' "
Then she brought him to her people, carrying him. They said, "O Mary, you have certainly done a thing unprecedented.
O sister of Aaron, your father was not a man of evil, nor was your mother unchaste."
So she pointed to him. They said, "How can we speak to one who is in the cradle a child?"
[Jesus] said, "Indeed, I am the servant of Allah. He has given me the Scripture and made me a prophet.
And He has made me blessed wherever I am and has enjoined upon me prayer and zakah as long as I remain alive
And [made me] dutiful to my mother, and He has not made me a wretched tyrant.
And peace is on me the day I was born and the day I will die and the day I am raised alive."

a.g: That is Jesus, the son of Mary - the word of truth about which they are in dispute.
It is not [befitting] for Allah to take a son; exalted is He! When He decrees an affair, He only says to it, "Be," and it is.
[Jesus said], "And indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. That is a straight path."
Then the factions differed [concerning Jesus] from among them, so woe to those who disbelieved - from the scene of a tremendous Day.
How [clearly] they will hear and see the Day they come to Us, but the wrongdoers today are in clear error.
And warn them, [O Muhammad], of the Day of Regret, when the matter will be concluded; and [yet], they are in [a state of] heedlessness, and they do not believe.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
Look, O wretched one, at these terrors and know that Allah the Exalted created the Fire with its terrors and created people who neither increase nor decrease, and that this matter has been decreed and finished with. Allah the Exalted said: 'And warn them of the Day of Regret when the matter is decreed while they are in heedlessness and they do not believe.' {} By my life, the reference is to the Day of Resurrection, but rather in pre-eternity (al-Azal), but on the Day of Resurrection what was preceded by the decree becomes manifest. So the wonder is from you where you laugh and play and busy yourself with the trivialities of the worldly life (al-Dunya) and you do not know what the decree has preceded concerning your right; if you say: 'Would that I knew what my source is and to what my end and return is, and what the decree has preceded concerning my right,' then for you is a sign by which you find comfort and confirm your hope because of it, and it is that you look at your states and your deeds, for each is facilitated for what he was created for. If the path of good has been facilitated for you, then give glad tidings, for you are kept far from the Fire. And if you do not intend good except that obstacles surround you and repel it, and you do not intend evil except that its causes are facilitated for you, then know that you are decreed against. For the indication of this upon the outcome is like the indication of rain upon vegetation and the indication of smoke upon fire. Indeed Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed the righteous are in bliss and indeed the wicked are in a Blazing Fire.' {} So present your soul (Nafs) upon the two verses and you have known your abode from the two abodes, and Allah knows best.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Intention, Sincerity, and Truthfulness
The virtue of Truthfulness (Sidq). Allah the Exalted said: 'Men who were true (Sadaqu) to what they promised Allah.' And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Indeed, truthfulness (Sidq) guides to righteousness (Al-Birr) and righteousness guides to Paradise. And a man may be truthful until he is recorded with Allah as a Truthful One (Siddiq). And indeed, falsehood (Kadhib) guides to wickedness (Al-Fujur) and wickedness guides to the Fire. And a man may lie until he is recorded with Allah as a liar.' And it suffices for the virtue of truthfulness that 'The Truthful One (Al-Siddiq)' is derived from it. And Allah the Exalted described the Prophets with it in the context of praise and commendation, saying: 'And mention in the Book (Al-Kitab) Ibrahim. Indeed, he was a Truthful One (Siddiq), a Prophet (Nabiyy).' And He said: 'And mention in the Book (Al-Kitab) Isma'il. Indeed, he was true to his promise (Sadiq al-Wa'd) and was a Messenger (Rasul), a Prophet (Nabiyy).' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And mention in the Book (Al-Kitab) Idris. Indeed, he was a Truthful One (Siddiq), a Prophet (Nabiyy).'

And how can the division be balanced when deficiency occurs on His side and perfection in His creation and craftsmanship? Or how can the argument of Abraham (peace be upon him) against his father be sound when he was worshipping idols out of ignorance and error, and he said to him: 'Why do you worship what does not hear, nor see, nor avail you anything?' And if that were reversed upon him regarding his worshipped one, his argument would become invalid and his proof would fall, and the saying of Allah the Exalted would not be truthful: 'And that was Our argument which We gave Abraham against his people.' And just as one comprehends His being an Actor without a limb and a Knower without a heart and brain, let him comprehend His being a Seer without a pupil and a Hearer without an ear, for there is no difference between them.

So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the path how He made it easy for him, and to the transgression of the human being (InsÄn) how ungrateful he is, and to the ignorance of the human being how He manifested it? For the verse indicated that the human being worships what does not hear and does not see and does not avail him anything, and this is the utmost ignorance (Jahl) and heedlessness (Ghaflah). So how does he worship what is inferior to him? And this is the utmost foolishness (HamÄqah) and ignorance (Jahl).

ğŸ“– Vol 2: Etiquette of Seclusion
Mentioning the arguments of those inclined toward preferring isolation, they argued with His saying, the Exalted, narrating from Abraham, peace be upon him: 'And I will withdraw from you and what you call upon besides Allah, and I will call upon my Lord. Perhaps I will not be in calling upon my Lord unhappy.' Then Allah said: 'So when he withdrew from them and what they worship besides Allah, We gave him Isaac and Jacob, and each We made a prophet.' Indicating that this was by the blessing (Barakah) of isolation. And this is weak because mixing with disbelievers has no benefit except calling them to the religion, and when despairing of their response, there is no aspect except abandoning them. Rather, the discussion is about mixing with Muslims and what is in it of blessing (Barakah), as it was narrated that it was said: 'O Messenger of Allah, ablution (Wudu) from a sealed jug is more beloved to you or from these public water sources from which people purify themselves?' He said: 'Rather from these public water sources,' seeking the blessing (Barakah) of the hands of Muslims. The hadith: It was said to him, peace be upon him: 'Ablution (Wudu) from a sealed jug is more beloved to you or from these public water sources from which people purify themselves?' He said: 'Rather from these public water sources.' The hadith was reported by Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat from the narration of Ibn Umar, and there is weakness in it. And it was narrated that when he, peace be upon him, circumambulated the House, he turned to Zamzam to drink from it, and there was the dates soaked in leather basins, and the people had mixed it with their hands, and they were taking from it and drinking. He asked for drink from it and said: 'Give me to drink.' Al-Abbas said: 'This is a drink that has been mixed and stirred with hands. Shall I not bring you a drink cleaner than this from a sealed jug in the house?' He said: 'Give me to drink from this from which the people drink, seeking the blessing (Barakah) of the hands of Muslims.' So he drank from it. The hadith: When he circumambulated the House.

And its rivers flow upon pebbles of ruby and emerald, and its roots, palms, and vines are pearls, and its fruitsâ€”none knows their knowledge except Allah the Exalted. And its fragrance is found from a journey of five hundred years. And they have therein horses and camels, light, their saddles, bridles, and saddles of ruby; they visit each other therein, and their spouses are the wide-eyed maidens, as if they were hidden pearls. For them is their provision therein morning and evening. But indeed, there is no night; the morning alternates with the evening and the evening with the morning. And the last to enter Paradise and the lowest in rankâ€”his sight and his dominion are extended for a journey of one hundred years in palaces of gold and silver and tents of pearl, and his sight is expanded until he sees its farthest as he sees its nearest. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
And the worst type of arrogance (Kibr) is what prevents from benefiting from knowledge and accepting the truth and submitting to it, and in it came the verses which contain condemnation of arrogance (Kibr) and the arrogant ones. Allah the Exalted said: "And the angels will be spreading their hands" up to His saying: "and you were arrogant (Tastakbirun) about His signs." Then He said: "Enter the gates of Hell, abiding eternally therein, and wretched is the residence of the arrogant (Mutakabbirin)." Then He informed that the most severely punished of the people of the Fire are those most insolent (Atiyyan) against Allah the Exalted, so He said: "Then We will surely extract from every sect (Shi'ah) those of them who were most insolent (Atiyyan) against the Most Merciful." And He said: "So those who do not believe in the Hereafter - their hearts (Qulub) are denying and they are arrogant (Mustakbirun)." And He the Mighty and Majestic said: "Those who were oppressed will say to those who were arrogant (Istakbaru): 'If not for you, we would have been believers.'" And He said: "Indeed, those who are arrogant (Yastakbirun) about My worship will enter Hell humiliated." And He said: "I will turn away from My signs those who are arrogant (Yatakabbarun) on the earth without right." It is said in the interpretation (Tafsir): I will lift the understanding of the Quran from their hearts (Qulub), and in some interpretations (Tafasir) I will veil their hearts (Qulub) from the dominion (Malakut). And Ibn Juraij said: I will turn them away from reflecting upon them and taking admonition from them.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
So it is astonishing that we do not take heed from him, and we are not confident in what we will encounter. Rather, we are captives of desires (Shahawat) and companions of sins (Ma'asi) and evil deeds (Sayyi'at). So why do we not learn a lesson from the death of Muhammad, the master of the messengers (Sayyid al-Mursalin) and the leader of the God-fearing (Imam al-Muttaqin) and the beloved of the Lord of the worlds (Habib Rabb al-'Alamin)? Perhaps we think that we are immortal, or we imagine that we, with our evil actions, are honored before Allah! Far from it, far from it! Rather, we are certain that we are all entering the Fire (al-Nar) as entrants (Waridun), then none will be saved from it except the God-fearing (al-Muttaqun). So we are certain of the entering (al-Wurud) and we imagine the emerging (al-Sudur) from it. No, rather we have wronged ourselves if we are waiting for the predominant assumption (Ghalib al-Zann) in such a manner, for we are not, by Allah, from the God-fearing (al-Muttaqin). And Allah, the Lord of the worlds, has said: 'And there is none of you but will come to it (enter it). This is upon your Lord a decree (Hatm) determined (Maqdi). Then We will save those who feared (ittaqaw) and leave the wrongdoers (al-Zalimin) therein on their knees (Jithiyyan).' So let every servant (Abd) look at himself: is he closer to the wrongdoers (al-Zalimin) or to the God-fearing (al-Muttaqin)? Then look at yourself after you look at the conduct of the righteous predecessors (al-Salaf al-Salihin), for they were, with what they were granted, from the fearful (al-Kha'ifin). And this witnessing (Mushahadah) and manifestation (Tajalli) is what is called vision (Ru'yah). Therefore, the vision is true, provided that one does not understand from the vision the completion of imagination (Khayal) in an imagined, conceived thing specified with direction and place; for that is something from which the Lord of lords is greatly exalted. Rather, just as you knew Him in this world with a true, complete knowledge (Ma'rifah) without imagination (Takhayyul) and conception (Tasawwur) and estimation of form and image, so you will see Him in the Hereafter likewise. Rather, I say: The knowledge (Ma'rifah) attained in this world itself is what becomes perfected so it reaches the perfection of unveiling (Kashf) and clarity (Wuduh) and transforms into witnessing (Mushahadah). And there is no difference between the witnessing in the Hereafter and what is known in this world except in terms of the increase in unveiling (Kashf) and clarity (Wuduh) as we have given the example.

And likewise, Allah the Exalted described the statement of Al-'As ibn Wa'il when he says "I will certainly be given wealth and children." So Allah the Exalted responded to him, saying "Has he known the unseen or taken a covenant with the Most Merciful? No!" And it is narrated from Khabbab ibn al-Aratt that he said: I had a debt upon Al-'As ibn Wa'il, so I came to demand it from him, but he did not settle it for me. So I said: I will take it in the Hereafter; he said to me: When you reach the Hereafter, then indeed I have there wealth and children, I will settle you from it. So Allah the Exalted revealed His saying "Have you seen the one who disbelieved in Our signs and said, 'I will surely be given wealth and children'?"[6] And Allah the Exalted said "And if We give him a taste of mercy from Us after adversity has touched him, he will surely say, 'This is due to me, and I do not think the Hour will occur; but if I am returned to my Lord, indeed, for me there will be with Him the best.'" And all of this is from delusion (Ghurur) regarding Allah.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
Then reflect after these terrors upon the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'On the Day when We will gather the God-fearing (Al-Muttaqin) to the Most Merciful (Al-Rahman) as a delegation, and drive the criminals to Hell as a thirsty herd' (Quran 19:85-86) and upon His saying: 'So guide them to the path (Siraat) of Hell. And stop them; indeed, they are to be questioned' (Quran 37:23-24). The people, after these terrors, are driven to the Bridge (Al-Siraat), which is a bridge extended over the back of the Fire, sharper than the sword and finer than a hair. Whoever was upright in this world upon the Straight Path (Al-Siraat al-Mustaqim) will be light upon the Bridge of the Hereafter and be saved, and whoever deviated from uprightness in the world and burdened his back with sins (Awzar) and disobeyed will stumble at the first step of the Bridge and fall. So reflect now upon what befalls your heart (Fu'ad) of terror when you see the Bridge and its fineness, then your sight falls upon the blackness of Hell beneath it, then your hearing is struck by the roaring of the Fire and its rage, and you have been tasked to walk upon the Bridge with the weakness of your state and the agitation of your heart (Qalb) and the trembling of your foot and the burden of your back with sins (Awzar) preventing you from walking on the carpet of the earth, let alone the sharpness of the Bridge. How will it be with you when you place one of your feet upon it and feel its sharpness and are compelled to lift the second foot, and the creatures before you slip and stumble, and the guards of the Fire pull them down with hooks and grappling irons, and you look at them how they are overturned so that their heads descend toward the direction of the Fire and their legs rise. Oh, what a sight, how dreadful it is, and what an ascent, how difficult it is, and what a passage, how narrow it is. So look at your state as you crawl upon it and ascend to it while you are burdened in the back with your sins (Awzar), turning right and left.

And His saying, the Exalted: 'On the Day when We will gather the God-fearing (Al-Muttaqeen) to the Most Merciful (Ar-Rahman) as a delegation' (Quran 19:85) - these two verses - and His saying, the Exalted: 'And there is none of you except he will come to it' (Quran 19:71) - the verse - and His saying: 'Do whatever you will' (Quran 41:40) - the verse - and His saying: 'Whoever desires the harvest of the Hereafter, We increase for him in his harvest' (Quran 42:20) - the verse - His saying: 'So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it' (Quran 99:7) - these two verses - and His saying, the Exalted: 'And We will present what they have done of deeds' (Quran 25:23) - the verse - and likewise His saying, the Exalted: 'By time, indeed, mankind is in loss' (Quran 103:1-2) - to the end of the Surah. These are four conditions for salvation from loss. And the fear of the Prophets, despite the abundant blessings that overflowed upon them, was because they did not feel secure from the plan (Makra) of Allah, the Exalted: 'So none feels secure from the plan (Makra) of Allah except the people who are the losers' (Quran 7:99). Until it was narrated that the Prophet and Gabriel, peace be upon them both, wept out of fear of Allah, the Exalted, so Allah revealed to them: 'Why do you weep when I have given you security?' They said: 'And who feels secure from Your plan (Makra)?' [90] And it was as if they, since they knew that Allah is the Knower of the unseen and that they have no standing upon the ultimate matters, did not feel secure that His saying 'I have given you security' might be a trial and a test for them and a plan (Makra) against them, so that if their fear subsided, it would become apparent that they had felt secure from the plan (Makra) and had not fulfilled their saying. Just as when Abraham, peace be upon him, was placed in the catapult, he said: 'Sufficient for me is Allah (Hasbunallahu)', and this was among the great supplications, so he was tested and confronted by Gabriel in the air until he said: 'Do you have any need?' He replied: 'As for from you, no.' That was a fulfillment of the reality of his saying 'Sufficient for me is Allah'. So Allah, the Exalted, informed about him, saying: 'And Abraham who fulfilled' - meaning, by the implication of his saying 'Sufficient for me is Allah'. And with the like of this, He informed about Moses, peace be upon him, when he said: 'Indeed, we fear that he will hasten [punishment] against us or that he will transgress.' He said: 'Fear not. Indeed, I am with you both; I hear and I see' (Quran 20:45-46). And despite this, when the magicians threw their magic, Moses felt fear within himself, for he did not feel secure from the plan (Makra) of Allah, and the matter became confused for him until reassurance was renewed for him and it was said to him: 'Fear not. Indeed, you are the highest' (Quran 20:68). And when the strength of the Muslims weakened on the day of Badr, he, peace be upon him, said: 'O Allah, if You destroy this group, there will remain no one on the face of the earth who worships You [91].' So Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'Leave off your pleading with your Lord, for He is faithful to you with what He promised you.' So the station of Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, was the station of trust in the promise of Allah, and the station of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was the station of fear from the plan (Makra) of Allah, and it is more complete because it does not issue except from perfection of knowledge of the secrets of Allah, the Exalted, and the hidden aspects of His actions and the meanings of His attributes, some of which are expressed as plan (Makra). And no one from mankind has the ability to stand upon the reality (Kunh) of the attributes of Allah, the Exalted. And whoever knows the reality (Haqiqah) of knowledge, the deficiency of his knowledge from encompassing the reality (Kunh) of matters, his fear inevitably becomes great. And for that reason, the Messiah, peace be upon him, said when it was said to him: 'Did you say to the people, "Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah"?' He said: 'Exalted are You! It was not for me to say that to which I have no right. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within myself, and I do not know what is within Yourself' (Quran 5:116). And he said: 'If You should punish them - indeed they are Your servants; but if You forgive them - indeed it is You who is the Exalted in Might, the Wise' (Quran 5:118) - the verse. He delegated the matter to the Will (Mashiyyah) and removed himself entirely from between, knowing that he has nothing of the matter and that matters are connected to the Will (Mashiyyah) with a connection that goes beyond the limits of the intelligible and the customary, so it is not possible to judge them by analogy, conjecture, or calculation, let alone by verification and certainty. And this is what cut the hearts (Qulub) of the knowers (Al-Arifeen), for the greatest calamity is the connection of your matter to the Will (Mashiyyah) of One who does not care about you; if He destroys you, He has destroyed your like from those who cannot be enumerated, and He has not ceased in the world to punish them with types of pains and illnesses, and He sickens from that their hearts (Qulub) with disbelief and hypocrisy, then He makes the punishment eternal upon them forever. Then He informs about Himself and says: 'And if We had willed, We could have given every soul its guidance, but the word from Me will come into effect: "I will surely fill Hell with jinn and men all together"' (Quran 32:13). And He, the Exalted, said: 'And the word of your Lord has been fulfilled: "I will surely fill Hell"' (Quran 11:119) - the verse. So how can one not fear what has been decreed from the word in pre-eternity and not hope to recover it? And if the matter were otherwise, hopes would extend to a stratagem therein, but there is only submission therein and inferring the hidden precedent (As-Sabiqah) from the apparent causes evident upon the heart (Al-Qalb) and the limbs. So for whom the causes of evil are facilitated and he is prevented from the causes of good and his attachment to the world is firmly established, it is as if the secret of the precedent (As-Sabiqah) that preceded for him with wretchedness has been unveiled to him in reality, for 'every [person] is facilitated for what he was created' (Hadith). And if all good deeds are facilitated and the heart (Al-Qalb) is completely cut off from the world and with its outward and inward turned towards Allah, this would necessitate a lessening of fear if constancy upon that were assured. But the danger of the ending (Al-Khatimah) and the difficulty of steadfastness increase the flames of fear in ignition and do not allow them to be extinguished. And how can one feel secure from a change of state when the heart (Qalb) of the believer is between two fingers of the fingers of the Most Merciful, and the heart (Al-Qalb) is more fluctuating than the pot in its boiling? And the Turner of the hearts (Muqallib Al-Qulub), Glory be to Him, has said: 'Indeed, the punishment of their Lord is not that from which one is safe' (Quran 70:28). So the most ignorant of people is he who feels secure from Him while He calls out with warning against security. And if Allah were gentle with His knower (Al-Arifeen) servants by reviving their hearts (Qulub) with the spirit (Ruh) of hope, their hearts (Qulub) would burn from the fire of fear. So the causes of hope are a mercy for the chosen ones of Allah, and the causes of heedlessness are a mercy upon the common people of creation from one aspect, for if the covering were unveiled, the souls (An-Nufus) would expire and the hearts (Al-Qulub) would be severed from fear of the Turner of the hearts (Muqallib Al-Qulub). Some of the knowers (Al-Arifeen) said: 'If there were between me and one whom I knew with Oneness (At-Tawhid) a barrier for fifty years and he died, I would not affirm for him Oneness (At-Tawhid) because I do not know what appeared to him of fluctuation.' And some of them said: 'If the testimony were at the door of the house and death upon Islam were at the door of the room, I would choose death upon Islam because I do not know what occurs to my heart (Qalbi) between the door of the room and the door of the house.' And Abu Ad-Darda' would swear by Allah that no one feels secure about his faith that it will not be stripped from him before death except that it is stripped. And Sahl would say: 'The fear of the truthful ones (As-Siddiqeen) from a bad ending (Sou' Al-Khatimah) is at every thought (Khatrah) and at every movement, and they are those whom Allah, the Exalted, described when He said: 'And their hearts (Qulubuhum) are fearful' (Quran 23:60).

Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'How can I enjoy comfort when the possessor of the Trumpet (Sahib al-Sur) has taken the horn in his mouth, lowered his forehead, and listened with his ear, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow?' [144] Muqatil said: The Trumpet (al-Sur) is the horn, and that is because Israfil (upon him be peace) has placed his mouth on the horn like the form of a trumpet, and the circumference of the head of the horn is like the expanse of the heavens and the earth, and he is staring with his gaze toward the Throne, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow the first blowing. When he blows, those in the heavens and the earth are struck unconscious, meaning every living creature dies from the intensity of the terror, except whom Allah wills, and that is Jibril, Mika'il, Israfil, and the Angel of Death (Malak al-Mawt). Then the Angel of Death is commanded to take the soul (Ruh) of Jibril, then the soul (Ruh) of Mika'il, then the soul (Ruh) of Israfil, then the Angel of Death is commanded and he dies. Then the creation remains after the first blowing in the Intermediate State (al-Barzakh) for forty years. Then Allah, the Exalted, revives Israfil and commands him to blow the second blowing, and that is His saying, the Exalted: 'Then it will be blown into it another time, and behold, they are standing, looking on' [Quran 39:68], on their feet, looking at the Resurrection. And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'When I was sent, I was sent to the possessor of the Trumpet (Sahib al-Sur), and he inclined it to his mouth, and advanced one foot and delayed another, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow. Indeed, fear the blowing!' [145] So reflect on the creation and their humiliation, their brokenness, and their submission at the time of resurrection, out of fear of this unconsciousness and waiting for it.

And look at Pharaoh, Haman, Korah, and the kings of the earth and what happened to them - how Allah bestowed favor upon them initially, then destroyed them utterly! So Allah the Exalted said: "Do you perceive from them anyone?" The verse. And Allah the Exalted has warned of His deception (makr) and gradual entrapment (istidrÄj), saying: "So none feels secure from the deception (makr) of Allah except the people who are losers," and Allah the Exalted said: "And they planned a plan, and We planned a plan, while they perceived not," and He the Mighty and Majestic said: "And they planned, and Allah planned, and Allah is the best of planners," and Allah the Exalted said: "Indeed, they are planning a plan, and I am planning a plan.
